Comment: It was like watching the odometer on my car roll over from 99,999 to 100,000 - seemed to take forever. But this is the game that tipped the rating into the Expert realm. This is a Fast Ladder game. I challenged as far up the lader as it would let me, and this game is the result. It's a bloody one, which seems quite befitting for my advent into Expertdom. I begin by challenging 1. e4 with the Sicilian.

3. g3 was an interesting choice. Evidently playable, but not any of white's main replies. Apparently Fischer played it once with crushing success. I reply by developing.

To cover the hole on d5, prepare a push to d5, and to be immune to a possible future pin by a white bishop on g5.

8. Qb3 is a little bit of a fork. The queen forks black's pawn on b7, tying the DSB down to defense, and black's pawn on f7 which comes into real danger after the inevitable 9. Ng5. So I scrounged around for a solution and kept looking at 8. ... Be6. It obviously loses a pawn, but it keeps the kingside safe. Is it worth it? So I analyzed it a bit further and realized fairly quickly that the b7 pawn is quite safe.

8. Qb3 is a little bit of a fork. The queen forks black's pawn on b7, tying the DSB down to defense, and black's pawn on f7 which comes into real danger after the inevitable 9. Ng5. So I scrounged around for a solution and kept looking at 8. ... Be6. It obviously loses a pawn, but it keeps the kingside safe. Is it worth it? So I analyzed it a bit further and realized fairly quickly that the b7 pawn is quite safe.
Or so I thought. This is where white should have asked why his opponent blundered away a pawn. The answer is quite tragic for the far-flung white queen, so far from home and all alone.
